content.webTitle: Travel view: Get ahead, be first into Libya

fields.headline: Get ahead, be first into Libya
fields.bodyText: Say the word Libya to most Brits and the second word to trip off the tongue is still likely to be Lockerbie. But for many people who've been there, the next words are Leptis Magna, regarded as the world's finest remaining Roman city. Tony Blair's relation-restoring visit to Libya last week was reassuring and sent many of us scurrying to our atlases to see what we were missing. Just a British Airways three hours and 45 minutes flight away, with good weather, fantastic Roman architecture and desert tours, Libya is likely to be the 'in' place to become a travel bore about. While everyone else is going on about new EasyJet destinations Budapest and Ljubljana and the like, you can go for the exotic edge. Remember what Michael Portillo's visit to the Roman ruins of Volubilis in Morocco did for tourism there during the 2001 Tory leadership contest? The boom that followed was phenomenal. Libya could be next. Remember, though, to allow at least six weeks to get a visa. Hugh Fraser of Cox & Kings (020 7873 5000), which offers tours there, says that, first, your passport must be translated into Arabic. Accommodation outside the capital, Tripoli, which has one five-star hotel, varies 'from basic to very basic', he says. Women are treated equally. His firm has seven-night breaks from £999, including BA flights, accommodation, a guide, most meals and transfers.
